intro: Monanthotaxis aestuaria, commonly known as the salt marsh sedge, is a flowering plant native to coastal regions of the southeastern United States. It is a perennial herb that thrives in brackish or saline wetlands, often found in tidal marshes and estuaries. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces small, clustered flowers that are typically greenish or brownish in color. Its rhizomatous growth habit allows it to spread and stabilize soil in its habitat. Monanthotaxis aestuaria plays an important ecological role in coastal ecosystems by providing habitat and stabilizing shorelines.
